div.head:
The Egyptian Gazette
THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager--R. Snelling.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
THE ZIONIST CONGRESS.
div.p: Of all the Congresses now being held, says the "Globe" the Zionist meeting has attracted the least notice. Of course, the Peace Conference has drawn the most attention, for several reasons, but even the Esperantist Congress has received more notice than the Jewish gathering. The discussions have shown that there are two distinct parties among the Zionists the political, which is the most numerous and possessed of the greatest influence, and the realist, or practical group. The aim of the political Zionists is to obtain the consent of the Powers to the establishment of a Jewish State in Palestine, and to secure the union of all the scattered Jews as the means of bringing pressure to bear on the Governments of Europe. The practical Zionists insist that it is no use waiting for a problematical agreement, but that it is advisable to encourage emigration to Palestine, and to get possession of land and develop agricultural colonies. This view of the case has been pressed acting Committee with great vehemence, and the discussions have been exceedingly heated. But the outcome of it all is that Zionism seems to have lost ground. The diplomatic or politcal action has had no resuits. There are some countries, such as Spain and Morocco, where Zionism is unknown, and where no effort has been made to inspire a national feeling among the Jewish populations. The resources of the Committee are insufficient to carry on the propaganda, and the whole movement seem to have lost its force. It is possible, however, that the lively criticisms which have bee directed against the leaders will have the effect of reviving the enthusiasm and energy of the great mass of those who support the movement.

div.head: H.H.S. "Aida."
div.p: The Aida returned to Alexandna harbor yesterday evening from her cruise in the Red Sea.

div.head: Sultan of Zanzibar.
div.p: The Sultan of Zanzibar passed through the Suez Canal on Wednesday, on his way to visit Kink Edward in London.

div.head: Police Budget.
div.p: 12 thefts, 17 misdemeanours and 38 minor offenses came under the notice of the Cairo police in the course of the past 24 hours.

div.head: Plague.
div.p: Two fresh cases of bubonic plague and two recoveries were reported from Alexandria during the past 24 hours. Only 5 patients now remain under treatment throughout Egypt.

div.head: Burglary.
div.p: Two thieves, as yet unknown, broke into the house of Mohamed Bey Daoud, living in Darbel Saida, Cairo, on Thursday morning and stole L.E. 400 from a chest of drawers. The police are actively searching for the culprits.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: 110 fatal cases of cattle plague were reported throughout Egypt during the week ending 26th instant, of which 64 oceurred in Assiout province, 34 at Minia, 4 at Beni-Souef, 7 at Guizeh and 1 at Kalioubieh.

div.head: Sultans Anniversary.
div.p: By decision of the committee formed to superintend the arrangements of the fete in honour of the anniversary of H.H. The Sultan's accession, the Esbekieh Garden will be open for ladies only from 8 o'clock a.m. until midday.

div.head: Press Libel Case.
div.p: The libel case brought by Ahmed Bey Farid, manager of the "Etendard Egyptien," against Nachet Bey, member of the liberal party, came before the Summary Tribunal of Abdine yesterday and was postponed for three weeks owing to the indisposition of the defendant.

div.head: The Athambra Theatre.
div.p: This evening the French comedy troupe under the management of Mr. Galenzi, which arrived from France on Tuesday, will make its debut at the Alhambra theatre, the five act comedy "Triplepatte," by Messrs. Tristan Bernard and Andre Godfernaux, having been chosen for the occasion.

div.head: Attempted Murder.
div.p: A ruffianly Italian, named Mantalupo, on Wednesday tried to murder his mistress in Sharia Luxemburg, whom he had approached disguised as a Bedouin, but fortunately a shawish was close at hand and succeeded in effecting his arrest. Mantalupo has been handed over to his Consulate.

div.head: The Catacloum.
div.p: The Catacloum, which can be best described as an Alexandrian chat noir de Paris, continues to attract a considerable number of people. Many of the songs, which are chiefly local and topical, such as humorous verses about the crisis, the director of Egypt's three notorious newspapers, and other public nuisances are most cleverly composed and very well rendered.

div.head: Automobile Accident.
div.p: A serious accident, which resulted in the death of a young man belonging to one of the best known Cairo native families, took place on Wednesday night, on the road to the Pyramids. Mohamed Aly Shawki, son of Shawki Bey, had invited two friends among whom was the son of Ooff Pasha, for a ride in his automobile, driven by a native chauffeur. They were going at a good speed, when they hit against one of the tramway poles. The proprietor, a friend and the chauffeur jumped from the motor and escaped without serious injury. Unfortunately Ooff Bey was overturned and killed immediately. The motor was completely destroyed, and an enquiry has been opened to establish the responsibility.

div.head: An Hotel on Fire.
div.p: A fire broke out on Wednesday about 7:30 p.m. in the house of Erian Bey Chatby, Cairo, known as the "Hotel du Transvall." The apartment in which the fire occurred was occupied by Mme St. Martin, and let as furnished rooms. The berberin servant first discovered the smoke, and gave the alarm to his mistress. When she arrived the fire had already caught the wood partitions separating the rooms, and had penetrated to the salon. The lodgers, for the most part ladies, were absent and the affrighted landlady rushed into the street crying help. The fire brigade was informed and soon arrived on the scene. With considerable difficulty the fire was got under hand and for two hours the men laboured, drenching the place to prevent spreading. Nearly all the furniture was burnt or destroyed, and a number of the lodgers lost their dresses and jewels. The damages are said to be about 350.

div.head: UNITED EGYPTIAN SALT LIMITED.
div.p: Referring to the notice contained in our issue of the 12th inst. we understand that the above company has been, or is about to be formed for the purpose of carrying out the contracts recently entered into with the Salt and Soda Company; the Port Said Salt Association; and the Egyptian Markets, Limited.

The Salt and Soda Company and the Salt Association have agreed to co-operate in the formation of the intended new company with the intention that the principal objects of the intended new company shall be, first, the acquisition from the Salt and Soda Company of the benefit of the contracts with the Eqyptian Government except so far as concerns the working of the salines therein mentioned, and secondly, the acquisition of the exclusive right to purchase for resale and consumption in Egypt the salt produced by the Salt and Soda Company and the Salt Association respectively.

The Salt and Soda Company are entitled to the benefit of certain contracts dated respectively the 31st day of December 1905 and the 8th Day of May 1906 made between the Egpytian Government and the Salt and Soda Company relating to the sale of salt in Egypt. The Salt and Soda Company are also the owners of a Concession from the Egyptian Government dated the 2nd day of January 1901, as modified by agreement dated 13th March 1905 for the exclusive right to import into and sell in Egypt powder, saltpetre, and smokeless powder.

From the 1st day of October next the Markets have undertaken the exclusive agency for the sale of the products of the Salt and Soda Company and the Port Said Salt Association. The Markets are to receive a commission of 2 per cent on the total amount received from the sale of all the industrial products of the Salt and Soda Company, except soap, and on this latter they are to receive a commission of 2 1/2 per cent on the total amount received by the Markets for the sale of soap.
On powder the Markets are to receive a commission of 4 per cent on the total amount of sales.
As regards the sale of salt, the Markets are to have the exclusive Agency for this also, and are to receive a sum equivalent to 11 per cent on the amount of salt sold.

We understand that the shares of the United Egyptian Salt, Limited will be issued as fully paid, and that the Salt and Soda Company will take one half, and the Port Said Salt Association the other, the object of this intermediate Company being to simplify a somewhat complicated transaction. Last years salt returns throughout Egypt amounted to about 120,000 tons; of this about 85,000 tons were produced by the Salt and Soda Company, 16,000 tons by the Port Said Salt Association, and the remainder by the Damietta Salines.

As regards the Markets, assuming that the next years sales amount to only 90,000 tons at Piastres 180 per ton, the Markets would receive a gross sum of between 17,000 and 18,000 under the arrangement above referred to. To this sum must be added the amounts for commission which the Markets may receive on the sale of soap, powder and other products of the Salt and Soda Company.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN SITUATION.
div.p: A proposal of the difficulties which have lately made themselves felt in Egypt the "Globe" states that there is a growing disposition on the part of many students of the situation to believe that the worst is over in Egypt, and that matters are likely to mend before long. For the present, of course, stagmation prevails. It is when the time comes to move the crops that matters are expected to wake up again. This process will necessitate a considerable export of gold to Egypt, an export so large that it is not likely to be without its effect upon home monetary conditions. Cotton is the basis of Egyptian prosperity, and the coming crop promises well. Last year, it is believed, as much as 25,000,000 found its way into the pockets of the fellaheen as the proceeds of the cotton, and as much, or perhaps more, will gravitate in the same direction this year. Unfortunately, the fellaheen stolidly refuse to place this money in circulation. A large proportion of it is buried or secreted, and much gold is absolutely lost by the sudden demise of those who have carefully stored it, deliberately refraining from giving any relative the slightest hint as to its whereabouts. Lord Cromer did his best to induce natives to place their money with the banks; but htousands of them have not as yet got rid of the old habits of their forefathers. One thing seems likely, and that is that although general conditions in Egypt may shortly be expected to show improvement, the measure of that improvement will not be sufficiently great to warrant a resumption of those industrial flotations so many of which were launched by European financiers last year with such a problematical chance of earning returns for shareholders.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman liner "City of Oxford" sailed from Liverpool yesterday for Malta and Alexandria with a general cargo.
The Prince liner "Asiatic Prince" arrived this morning from Antwerp, London, and Malta with passengers, gunpowder, and general cargo.

div.head:
CYPRUS TRADE.
WINE GROWING.
div.p: Amongst the most important prodocts of the island of Cyprus, which are mostly agricultural (viz-barley, wheat, oats, caroubs, silk, olives, cotton, aniseed, linseed and hemp) one of the chief is the grape. The culture of the vine has been conducted in the island from the earliest times (the wines of Cyprus enjoyed great repute in the days of the Romans, amongst whom they were in constant use). In later days, however, when the island came under Turkish rule, for nearly three hundred years, little was heard of them, and much of the island that was formerly under vine culture was allowed to run to waste. A further blow was given to the island in the early nineties when the French, who had formerly taken the bulk of the Cyprus products, imposed a prohibitive import duty. However since the British occupation efforts have been made, especially of late years, to increase the wine production, and on recent visit to the island we were shown over the largest winery established by an English syndicate at Perapedhi. It is sitaated about half way between Limassol and Troodos military road. This winery is laid out the most scientific and modern lines and equipped with the most up to date plant for the production of high class wines; its annual between 100,000 and 150,000 gallons of wine. Here various types of wine are made which compare favourably with those of the better known wine producing countries Sufficient capital has been provided to allow of the wines and brandy being thoroughly well matured before being put on the market.

The chief types of wine produced at this winery are Cyprus port and Cyprus burgundy which have both been well received in England, and we may mention "Vino de Pasto" a harming white wine of sherry character and "Commanderia" a fine rich dessert wine, in addition to these "Cyprus Madeira" and "Cyprus Marsala" have proved to be quite excellent.

We learned here that it was with the vines of Cyprus that Madeira was replanted alter the destruction of its vineyards in 1858. So far Cyprus has not been afflicted with that terrible scourge the phylloxera which has so affected other countries. Thanks to prohibitive legislation the importation of vines from other ountries has been stopped, and it is to be hoped that owing to this, Cyprus will be spared the ravages of this pest.

In conjunction with this winery at Pera pedhi there is also a distillery equipped with four stills and all requisite plant for making brandy. This brandy compares very favourably with that of the Charente districts in France, and has already become popular in England.

The total prodaction of the island is between three and three and a half million gallons annually, the majority being common native wines, both red and white, which are chiefly exported to Egypt. Most of this wine is made by the peasant proprietors who till their vineyards with the aid of their wives and children and although cultivating, as some suppose, their vineyards in a careless manner, they seem to be fairly successful. The trouble arises when vineyards are sequestrated or left uncared for thro' want of funds or some other cause and thus become centres for the spreading of various diseases. It is essential that the vineyards should be ploughed twice annualy but a third ploughing will more than repay the proprietor for his additional labour.

The villagers on the whole are intelligent ind willing to learn modern practice, and the efforts of the agricultural department by instructing them in these improved methods and the help given by the imports in and sale of sulphur at leas than cost price in order to aid the inhabitants to combat the oidium have maternally assisted in the progress of cultivation.
The chief centres of production are in the Limassol district viz., Vassa, Kilani, Omodhos, Mandria, Potamiou, Platras, Perapedhi, Vouni, Lophos and Arsos.

div.head:
BOURSE AND BANKING.
AN ABORTIVE MEETING.
div.p: The extraordinary meeting of tbe Share holders of the Bourse and Banking Co. Ltd., convened yesterday at the offices ot the Com pany in 26 Rue Cheriff Pacha for the purpose of considering and if thought fit of passing the Directors' resolution to wind up the Company volantarily, proved abortive in consequence of the insufficiency to form a quorum and the meeting stands adjourned for a week. About 50 proprietors were present; and two of the Directors, not in entire agreement with their colleagues, holding in their own right and by proxies a large amount, absented themselves from the meeting, which in consequence stands adjourned. Much comment was made at the array of legal talent represented at the meeting.

div.head:
AMERICAN COTTON REPORT.
UNFAVOURABLE FOR SPECULATION.
div.p: Under date of the 2ist inst. Messrs, Reynolds and Gibson report that cable advices to hand on that date were of a bearish natare. They state that rains are reported in many sections in the Southwest and that more is predicted.

The opening was quiet at 1 point decline, but there was rather a nervous undertone to the market. We soon eased off a couple of points on a little selling by houses with American connections. At midday the market was dull 2 1/2 decline.
During the early afternoon we eased slightly from these prices and when later on New York sent us a quiet opening we further eared here, 5 points decline being touched.
The market at this time looked rather poor, but when later on no selling developed, the jobbers who were running short, were forged to cover and this soon steadied up the market.
We finally closed firm at about the best of the day 1/2 point decline.
New York. Chapman Setter and Allan.
Showers Abilene Littlerock meridian.
The same firm also favours us with the following cotton reports from America:-
New York. S. Gruner and Co. August 9th

Financial conditions are certainly not of a nature to favor speculation just now and as regards the cotton crop the prospect with the exception of Texas appears to be most flattering. Due allowance should also be made for exaggeration in Texas. It is quite certain that accounts from that state are by no means unanimous about the damage done. It is also the fact that the drought does not extend over the whole state, and furthermore such weather as Texas is having may be a little severe, but, is nevertheless seasonable in August. Upon the whole therefore, we look upon the crop prospect as favorable and the chances still good for a very good yield.
New York. A Norden and Co. August 9th

Regarding the crop outlook, the attention of the trade is directed almost entirely to the situation in Texas, where there has been norelief from the long period of dry and hot weather. The small and backward condition of the plant makes it all the more liable to serious damage from this source, and unless the drought is broken in the near future, serious deterioration of the crop in South and Southwest Texas seems inevitable.
New York. Mohr Hanemann & Co August 9th.

There appears to be no demand worth mentioning from outside sources. Expectation that a general speculative demand would set in, will apparently have to be given up for the present. The outlook is, that we shall have to await further weather conditions, and the attitude of the South regarding the offerings and prices asked when the new crop commences to move. It is thought that the demand from spinners then, will show how great their needs are, and their determination to lose no time in supplying their wants to their full ability, which will impart the strength and confidence necessary to induce the public to become largely interested.

The trade reports from nearly everywhere are to the same purport, a continued large demand for goods, not only for the late delivery, but far into the future, contracte have been made for the late deliveries, based on considerably higher prices for cotton than are now ruling.
New Orleans, C.P. Ellis & Co. August 9th.

The principal short interest has remained immovable until to-day, when the buying of upwards of 100,000 bales of winter months for this account was one of the conspicuous characteristics of the trading. Those who have been resisting daily bear attacks for some time past appear to have taken advantage of this demand to lighten or abandon the holdings, but the general market continues to display a condition of inherent merit which is not at all surprising when contrasted to the amazing prices being paid for early receipts of new cotton, for immediate use. Of course, the removal or reduction of so extensive a short interest cannot be regarded as strengthening the technical position, but at the same time liquidation has been simultaneously extensive, and the situation is therefore a healthy one. Rains in Texas would in all likelihood precipitate a break because of liquidation by smaller holders who are long on the droughty conditions, but on any substantial depression so created, we would again favor purchases until Europe evinces a disposition to resist the advance, beenase of restricted trade demand, which is not now manifest.
New Orleans. H. & B. Beer & Co. August 10th.

The fine dry weather during June was just what was desired, but as it continued dry during most of July the crop was left in danger of serious injury from August drought, which now seems to have developed. The most unfavorable feature in connection with this unusually long period of fair weather has been the high temperature, this being the 18th, day of abnormal heat, the average maximum ranging from 96 @ 98 degrees with but one exception when it was lowered to 94. The Southwestern portion of the state, formerly the most favored section of the belt this season, was the first to complain; then the drought area extended to the central counties, and now the more northern district are being threatened. The supposition is that this is the most unfavorable development that could have overtaken the crop, as owing to its lateness it is in a critical condition, and unless beneficial rains make their appearance the coming week prices are apt to seek a still higher level, although dangerously high already.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Lieutenant J. E. Gibbe, Colstream Guards, has been selected for the appointment of aide de camp to Lord Minto, Viceroy of India.
Colonel Skinner, an officer well known in Egypt, where he served with the Khedive's army, has just retired from the command of the 1st Battalion Royal Summer Regiment, Ambala, Punjab.

It appears that the best shot of the Mediterranean Fleet with the 12 inch gun is Petty Officer A. H. Bailey of the battleship "Formidable." His score was 7 hits out of 8 rounds, and all shots hit the target.

The 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, Colonel F. P. English, D.S.O. commanding will move from Kilworth Camp to Ballyvonare Camp on the 19th inst for battalion and brigade drills and training, along with the other units of the 16th Infantry Brigade.

The Egyptian draft of the Dublins, the men of which are now on leave will embark on the S.S. Sicilia at Southampton on the 25th September next for conveyance to Alexandria, where the 1st Battalion is stationed. The draft masters 90 non-commissioned officers and men, and will be followed later in the trooping season by another one of similar strength.

An old King's Own Scottish Borderer has just gone off the active list by the retirement on retired pay of Colonel Sir H. G. Dixon, K.C.B. He was associated with the old 25th from 1868 till 1898, and subsequently commanded the regimental district. His active service career embraced the Afghan War, 1878-79, (medal) Soudan War, 1888 (medal, with clasp, 4th class Mejidie, mentioned in despatches) Nile Expedition, 1899, Chitral Expedition, 1895 (mentioned in despatches, C. B. medal with clasp) and the Seuth African War (mentioned in despatches, K.C.B., Queen's medal with four clasps, and A.D.C. to the King).

Captain J. G. Devenish, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, latterly in command of a company in the 2nd Battalion, Cairo, has severed his connection with the regiment, in which he held a commission from October, 1899, when he got his second lieutenancy from the 4th Battalion Royal Irish Regiment. He was with the Inniskillings in the South African War, and was badly wounded in his first action at Colenso, and was afterwards engaged in the actions Vaal Krantz, and Tugela Heights, where he was again severely wounded, and the succeeding operations in the Transvaal, including the actions of Belfast and Lydenburg, (Queens medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: A marriage will take place on September 7th between Madamoiselle Cleopatre Marcopoulo and Monsieur Leonidas Polity
Hassan Effendi Fouad, son of the advoeate Hussein Bey Sakr, has left for Cambridge University to take his science degree.

A marriage took place yesteneday between Monsieur Alfred Damiano of Smyrna, and Mlle Adele André Abouchar of this town. After the ceremony a dinner was given at the Windsor Hotel, and subsequently the couple left for Europe.

div.head:
Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L' Administration a |'honneur de"porter a Ja connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au lundi, trente Septembre prochain & midi au plus tard des offres pour la fourniture de dix huit millions de cartes non imprimées pour billets de Chemins de fer, suivant la liste, les échantillons et le Cahier des Charges dont un exemplaire sera mis 4 la disposition des inté- ressés sur leur demande au Bureau de Mr. Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary & Alexandrie et & celni de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux & Boulac (Caire) contre paiement de cent milliéines. Toute personne désirant prendre part a cette adjudication devra verser en méme temps quelle présente son offre, 4 la Caisse Centrale de |'Administration au Caire, one somme de vingt Livres Egyptiennes a titre de cantidn- nement. provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire aura 4 parfaire cette somme. jus- qu'a concurrence du dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agréée. Le' soumissions devront étre accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente millié- mes, ainsi que du regu du versement du cautionnement provisoire susdit. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé 4:— Monsieur le Directeur (Général des Chemins de fer de |'Etat, an Cajire. et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante : Soumission pour Ja fourniture.de "Cartes non imprimées pour billets de Chemins de fer." 'Tonte soumission faite ou déposée ultérien- rement an jonr et 4 l'heure ci-dessns désignés ne sera pas prise en considération, 1 Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter loffre la plas basse ni A donner suite ux soumiasions présentées,. Elle se réserve sen méme temps le droit de diviser la commanile, Le Caire, le 28 Aotit 1907. 80840-2-1

div.head:
Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs.
NOTICE.
div.p: The Administration has the honour to inform the Fublic that tenders will be received up to noon on Thursday, 10th October next, for the supply of Carriage Trimmings in strict accordance with the Administration's standard Samples which may be inspected at the Central Stores at Boulac (Cairo) and at Gabbary Stores (Alexandria), where a complete set may be obtained at the price of L.E. 0.800 (eight hundred milliemes). A Copy of the specification and lists relating to these supplies can also be obtained at the above addresses on payment of L.E. 0.200 (two hundred milliemes).

All persons desiring to take part in this adjudication must first lodge with the Central Treasury of the Administration at Cairo a sum of L.E. 25 (Twenty five Egyptian pounds) as a provisional guarantee and the successful tenderer will be required to increase this sum to the amount of ten per cent of his accepted offer.
Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of the value of thirty milliemes and be addressed by registered post to:-
The General Manager, Egyptian State Railways, Cairo.
under double envelope, the inner bearing the following inscription:—
"Offer for Carriage Trimmings." The Administration is not bound to accept the lowest or any offer, and reserves to itself the right of dividing the order.

div.head:
The United Egyptian Lands, Limited.
NOTICE.
div.p: For the information of shareholders I beg to state that this Company's Bankers in Egypt are now THE NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT, ALEXANDRIA, and all future Calls etc. will, therefore, be payable to them.
L. Des Clayes. Secretary in Egypt.

div.head: EASTERN TELEGRAPH CO. LTD.
div.p: AVERAGE TIME occupied in transmission of Egyptian telegrams from England to Alexandria on Thursday, 29th August, 1907.
OUTWARDS.
Between the hours of 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. (Cairo time)
Owing to the elevation to the Sultanate of Muley Hafid, who is marching on Rabat, at General Drude's request a reinforcement of two more battalions has been granted.(Reuter)
A statement has been issued emphasising that there was no question of an expedition to the interior. The Algeciras Act would be strictly interpreted.
Telegrams received here indicate that Muley Hafid is pacific and axious to make terms with the French. (Reuter)
1,600 men are embarking for Morocco. (H).
General Drude has the command of nearly 6,500 men, and will be able to operate within 30 kilometres round about Casablanca.(Havas)
The proclamation of Muley Hafid's appointment has been favourably received at Mazagan by both Moors and Europeans: the new regime is expected to bring quietness.(Reuter)

div.head:
FRANCE AND JAPAN.
FRENCH PRESIDENT DECORATED.

div.p: Mr. Kurino, the Japanese ambassador, has delivered to President Fallieres the Order of of the Chrysanthemum. They both expressed the conviction that the recent treaty will develop the cordial feeling between the two countries, and maintain the peace of the world. (Havas)

div.head:
AUSTRIA AND BULGARIA.
THE EMPEROR'S CONGRATULATIONS.

div.p: It is noteworthy, in connection with the recent conferences on the subject of the Balkans, that the Emperor Francis-Joseph has telegraphed to Prince Ferdinand of Bulgaria his heartiest congratulations on the twentieth aniversary of his accession. He expressed the wish that he may enjoy a long and_beneficent rule. (Reuter)

div.head:
PLOT AGAINST THE TSAR.
THREE CONSPIRATORS SENTENCED

div.p: Three of the accused in the plot against the life of the Tsar were condemned to death, others to prison or deportation, and six acquitted. (Havas)

The Tsar has telegraphed to Prince Ferdinand his congratulations, and expressed the hope that he may complete his great work for the welfare of Bulgaria which was united to Russia by the bonds of brotherhood. Three of the prisoners arrested in connection with the conspiracy to murder the Tsar and M. Stolypin have been sentenced to be hanged, and 9 others to long terms of imprisonment and exile: the rest have been acquitted. (Reuter)

div.head:
DECEASED WIFE'S SISTER BILL.
THE CHURCH'S CONDEMNATION.

div.p: The Archbishop of Canterbury has recommended the clergy not to celebrate Deceased Wife's sister marriages. (Reuter)
1050 bales of West African cotton were landed here yesterday, constituting a record shipment. (Reuter)

div.head: THE ENGLISH IN EGYPT.
div.p: Here is a book about Egypt by a man who speaks with authority says the "Manchester Cotrier" authority conferred by years of residence and. work in Egypt. It is not a mere Jaw-kook. It is an important contribation 'to the history of commerce in Egypt; and, further, it is a practical guide which ought to bein the hands of everyone who owns land or honses in Egypt or has invested in Egyp tian securities of any kind. Every Padgett. M.P., ought to read it. Ifthe hosts of some wandering Oriental gentlemen on a_ recent occasion had read it they would have talked less nonsense. On that particular occasion the hosts included Messrs, Robertson and Morton, members of Parlament, Sir Thomas Barclay, of Paris (who seems to pose as a sort of commercial Dugald Dalgetty—though he is only a solicitor), and sundry others even less known to fame or notoriety : the guests were equally unimportant. These inter-tribal mutual advertisement functions are becoming. merely a public nuisance. They obtain a passing notoriety for hosts and guests only through the lack of knowledge on the part of the sub-editors of newspapers. If Mr. Scott's book were read and digested by those mysterious persons who decree what is to be reported and what is to be ignored, we should not be invited to waste our time in reading the uninformed outponr ing of Oriental speculators. "on the job"—of disappointed 'seekers of minor administrative offices, of would-be politicians who have failed to find appreciation for their talents at home, and hope by the advertisement of a report of their crude speeches in English journals to pose as leaders of Egyptian thought. The problem of the government of Egypt is much more difficult than Mr. Robertson, M.P., imagines. He has spent a fortnight in Egypt, and knows all about a land whose inhabitants were skilled manufacturers andsupreme artists in sculpture and architecture thousands of years before his forbears had discovered the art of painting their bodies blue. We have all much to learn, but some of us are more modest than others. Mr. Robertson finds a fortnight enough for Egypt : Mr. Keir Hardie is devoting exactly the same amount of time to studying all the problems of India ! What should we think of the opinions of aChinaman, ignorant of any European tongue, who travelled in a fortnight from Moscow to London, via Berlin, Vienna, and Paris, and set himself up as an authority on the conditions of life, of commerce, and of agriculture in Europe ? That, however, is exactly the position which Mr. Keir Hardie proposes to assume. Ignorance makes a man conceited—a little knowledge makes him arrogant, more knowledge makes him humble. Now, as a corrective to peoplelike Mr. Robertson, M.P., and to all the other Labour members who think that because they know a little more than they did last year they have discov- ered all knowledge, let Mr. Scott's book be recommended. Let all of them,at any rate,who desire to use Egyptas the stalking horse of their personal advertisement, read this historical record of what has been, and this lucid statement of what is, written by a lawyer, not by a politician, and they will begin to recognise that they have still much study before them. Mr. Scott writes as a jurist with a full sense of the responsikility of one of his calling, Accuracy of statement, the constant reference, to authority for every fact adduced, the expectation that his book will be without flaw and will remain a permanent work of authority, have been constantly in his mind. It is nota record of opinion. It is an ordered logical and lucid statement of fact. When he gives us an opinion of his own, it is stated as is the charge of a judge toa jury. He weighs the evidence for and against, and leaves us to agree with him-or not, as our varying degree of intelligence may decide. Nobody has any right to hold, still less to express, any opinion on the present condition and future prospects of Egypt who has not mastered, at least, all Lord Cromer's annual reports, Lord Milner's fascina. ting book, Sir Auckland Coburn's more recent work, and Mr. Scott's "Foreigner in Egypt." Then, after a year or two in the country, a man may have a right to express an opinion. Politics is a science, just as chemistry or medicine. The fact that a man has been taken from his ordinary avocation as a railway guard, or a stonemason, or a miner, and made a member of the House of Commons, entitles him, no doubt, to represent his former and to exptess with authority their views and his own on matters affecting his former industry; but it makes him no more a politician—still less a statesman—than it makes him a physician or an engineer or a skilled practical brewer. Nobody would' call in Mr. Keir Hardie to pregoribe for him if he were suffering from appendicitis ; nobody would. ask Mr, Bell, of Derby, of Mr. Robertson, M.P., to advise him as to the best way of making beer. They have had no training in these matters. No more have they had any training in government; no more have they any knowledge of the many problems which arise when a nation of a higher civilisation leads oné used to subjection—not for centuries, but for thousands of years on the path towards peace and prosperity. The more one knows of Lord Cromer's work «in Egypt, the more one understands the difficulties under which he worked, the more one appreciates the necessary limitations of his power, the greater must. be one's admiration for the marvellous results he achieved. Mr. Scott's book enables you to understand not a few of the difficulties Lord Cromer had to contend with so far as concerned the interference of European Powers other than Great Britain. The position of every European in Egypt is regulated by the "capitulations,". These "capitulations" first began to be granted 'to foreigners in Egypt by Saladin in the Twelfth Century. Mr. Scott traces their development, from that day to this—when no change can be made in the laws affecting foreigners in Egypt without the consent of fourteen European Powers. Take an instance of the working of the present arrangements. A tradesman who has been resident in Egypt for many years is accused of murder. He claims to be a Russian subject, is therefore not amenable to the jurisdiction of any Egyptian tribunal. He is handed over to the Russian Consul and is deported to Russia to be tried, say, at Odessa, where, no evidence being forthcoming against him, save written depositions, he is perhaps sentenced to a light punishment, perhaps liberated. Take another instance of how the "capitulations" interfere with internal legislation, quoted by Mr. Scott: "It unfortunately happens that at the present time there is a marked increase of rabies. Muzzling orders can, and probably will, be enforced. But the sanitary advisers of the Government are clear that an efficacions adjunct to such an order would be a moderate annual licence tax on dogs: the legal advisers of the Government are equally clear that such a tax could not be effectivety enforced against Europeans," It is easy for Padgett, M.P. to say "Egypt ig now a civilised nation, abolish the capitulations, and let the courts and legislature of Egypt be as free from foreign control as are the courts and legislatures of every European nation." Padgett, M.P. must first learn a little history, and then acquire a knowledge of the existing facts. Then he may understand that the sarrender of privileges by fourteen separate European Powers is not to be had for the asking. Were Egypt able to convince the fourteen European Powers that her own judiciary was firmly established on a basis of learning, independence, and incorruptibility, some of Ahe privileges the subjects of foreign Powers enjoy might be surrendered. But it must be remembered that a large proportion of the foreign inhabitants of Egypt belong to small na- tions—e.g. 33.94 per cent of the European population of Egypt are Greeks. Greece will not willingly surrender any privilege, and the attempt to coerce Greece would raise international questions with the larger and stronger Powers in the East of Europe, which would involve retreat or war. Had Britain an Army as well as a Navy, it mightimposeits will to the great advantage of Egypt on the fourteen Eurpean Powers; but so long as the military power of Britain remains contemptible in the eyes Of every Russian we cannot dream ot aiding the freedom of Egypt otherwise than by the slow processes of diplomacy. It is depressing to note the fact that Germany's trade, with a gonseqaent interest in Egypt, is progressing by leaps and bounds. A few years ago Germany's trade with Egypt was nil; now it amounts nearly £3,000,000 a year. A few years ago Germany cared nothing about the "capitulations," and now there is a resident population of Germans, increasing yearby year, whose interests will not. be lost sight of by the Fatherland. Lord Cromer's latest legacy to Egypt was a scheme for the modificatcon of the "capitulations" —for the decrease of the power of. the fourteen European nations to hamper internal: legislation. Mr. Scott's examination of Lord Cromer's proposals is worth, and will certainly receive, the careful consideration of those responsible for the Government of Egypt. It should also becarefully read. by everyone who wishes to hold any intelligent views on the problems of the Land of the Sphinx.
*"The Law Affecting Foreigners in Egypt." By James Harry Scott, B.A. LL.M., Advocate, Lecturer at the Khedivial School of Law, Cairo, Edinburgh ; Green and Son.

div.head: THE LATEST "CURE" FOR SEA-SICKNESS.
div.p: The latest expounder of an infallible cure is a German doctor, who has made the discovery that sea-sickness has nothing whatever to do with the stomach, and that to gird oneself with tight belts is the height of folly. He declares that the trouble is due to action on the blood, and that the oscillations of the boat make the heart beat unequally, and thus send to the brain at one time too much blood, and at another time too little. The head is the part affected, and not the stomach, so that the true remedy for nausea is to compress the neck. This is all very well, says "The Globe," but compression of the neck has been known to produce worse results than seasickness, and it will therefore be well for sufferers to be moderate in the application of the "cure."

div.head:
THE COTTON MARKET.
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: The demand for Egyptians on the Spot has continued very limited, and prices have declined 1/16 plb. for all qualities except those of Fine, both Brown and Upper, which are rediiced 4.
In the Future market a very limited business has resulted and the following are the latest quotations :—

American Futures. The market this week has been quiet in tone and prices have had frequent but less important fluctuations, to-day's closing values being 4 1/2 @ 5 1/2 points higher than those of last Thursday.

There has been very little information about the Crop and that has been somewhat contradictory in character; there has undoubtedly been a some rainfall in Texas, but not a general break up of the hot and dry conditions. The Market has also been largely under the influence of the financial position and the weakness of the Stock and Share markets both here and in America. The Bureau report for this month is, not, we understand, to be issued until the 9th of next month, instead of the 3rd proximo, the usual date; for what reason this change of date is made we do not know.

div.head:
SOLOMON'S TEMPLE.
ITS HISTORY AND ITS STRUCTURE.
div.p: (By the Rev W. Shew Caldacott. Religious Tract Society. 6/-.) The Rev. Shaw Caldecott has followed up his book. "The Tabernacle" with an interesting volume on the Temple of Solomon. The subject is dealt with in a most thorough manner, and the book is illustrated, in addition to which a folded plan of the temple is given. Mr Caldecott in his introduction draws attention to the fact that the Bible is not a book of history but a book of religion, the Old Testament containing nothing with regard to the question of population, agriculture, commerce etc; which are necessary to the true history of a nation. Monumental records were used in the East from the earliest times, and there remains a good deal to be done yet in the way of exploration and research to solve the many problems which present themselves to scientists and anchaeologists. Dr Sayce, in a preface which he has contributed to this book, emphasizes the importance of systematic excavations being made throughout Egypt and Palestine. He also attaches great weight to the evidence which Mr. Caldecott produces, to show that the Temple, in common with other temples built throughout Western and Central Asia, was built upon an artificial platform, in order to raise the building above the great rivers. The care which has been given in the description of the Temple, its architecture, ornamentation, and its measurements, should make this book of great value to bible students.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways
div.p: Goods may be booked from this Company's system of nearly 1000 kilometres of line in the Delta to any stations on the Egyptian State Railways and the Helouan Line.
Public Telegraph Messages are also accepted at many stations.
For further information apply to the Company's Offices at Cairo, Alexandria, Tantah, Zagazig, Damanhour or Saida Zenab
